channel.title: The New Yorker
channel.description: Stay up to date on everything happening in The New Yorker and on newyorker.com.

channel.dc:subject: everything

item.title: This Week in Fiction: Tessa Hadley
item.description: Deborah Treisman talks with the writer Tessa Hadley, whose story, “Valentine,” appears in this week’s issue. “Valentine” is part of the novel “Clever Girl,” which will be published in the U.S. next winter.
item.dc:creator: Deborah Treisman

item.title: Tessa Hadley: “Valentine.”
item.description: Madeleine and I are waiting at the bus stop at the bottom of Beech Grove in our school uniforms: green print dresses, short white socks and sandals, blazers. In the summer, we are allowed to leave off our hated green felt hats. It’s June, and summer is thick . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Tessa Hadley

item.title: Sarah Stillman: Building your own drone.
item.description: One recent Saturday morning, in a suburb of Washington, D.C., an eight-year-old boy named Ethan Manners and his father, José (“as in table manners,” the father said), arrived at a party whose invitation read “Do you want to build your own drone?” The . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Sarah Stillman

item.title: Richard Brody: Shane Carruth’s “Upstream Color” and “Primer.”
item.description: Shane Carruth’s first feature, “Primer,” from 2004 (screening on April 4 at the Museum of the Moving Image), is a tour de force of low-budget science-fiction filmmaking. It’s set in the indie-style world of a low-rent high-tech start-up . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Richard Brody

item.title: Peggy O’Brien: “Crustaceans.”
item.description:
Just as I cross myself when a cat like a hearse Cuts across my path, as though I still believed, Before the summer goes, I’ll be damned If we don’t get to the beach and eat lobster.
I dive right in waves with frosty lion manes . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Peggy O’Brien

item.title: Paul Rudnick: “WonderPlanet.”
item.description: I’m Jyll Cimmaron Stelton, and every morning, even before I crawl out from under my down comforter, I grab my iPad and start to mommyblog. I always begin by composing a prayer of gratitude for my beautiful children: Sonnet, Cascade, Nebula, and the baby, Diaspora. I’m . . .
item.dc:creator: Paul Rudnick

item.title: Out Loud: A Writer Returns
item.description: David Remnick talks with Hisham Matar about leaving Libya as a boy, his father’s imprisonment andÂ disappearance,Â and returning to Libya in the wake of the Libyan revolution.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Mark Singer: Reverence for whales at the Museum of Natural History.
item.description: The creationist’s nightmare that is the newest exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History, “Whales: Giants of the Deep,” begins, fittingly, at the beginning. A succession of suspended-overhead skeletons makes the compelling case that a four-legged wolf-size carnivorous mammal that, fifty million . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Mark Singer

item.title: Lizzie Widdicombe: The Vice guide to the world.
item.description: Late in February, in the Ryugyong Chung Ju-yung Indoor Stadium, in Pyongyang, North Korea, ten thousand stiff-looking spectators in gray Mao suits gathered to watch a basketball game. Vice Media, the Brooklyn-based company, had arranged to have members of the Harlem Globetrotters—Anthony (Buckets) Blakes, Will . . .
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Widdicombe

item.title: Ken Auletta: At Business Insider, Henry Blodget’s second act.
item.description: The newsroom of Business Insider occupies the thirteenth floor of 257 Park Avenue South, overlooking the sidewalks and snail-mail concerns of Twenty-first Street. Rows of pressed-wood IKEA desks are lined up under a vast ceiling, and several dozen writers and editors tap away at keyboards and gaze . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Ken Auletta

item.title: Joan Acocella: Dance Theatre of Harlem returns.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">In 2004, Dance Theatre of Harlem went broke and had to suspend operations. A lot of us thought that was the end of the company. Fortunately, we were wrong. D.T.H., with a slimmed-down roster of eighteen dancers, is now in the middle of a cross-country . . .
item.dc:creator: Joan Acocella

item.title: Jeremy Denk: A life in piano lessons.
item.description: Two summers ago, I was playing concerts in Santa Fe, some five hours’ drive from where I grew up. Travel is more difficult for my parents than it used to be, but they made the trek to hear me. They brought along a strange gift—a black notebook . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Denk

item.title: James Wood: Rachel Kushner’s “The Flamethrowers.”
item.description: Put aside, for the moment, the long postwar argument between the rival claims of realistic and anti-realistic fiction—the seasoned triumphs of the traditional American novel on one side, and the necessary innovations of postmodern fiction on the other. It was never very edifying anyway, each camp busily . . .
item.dc:creator: James Wood

item.title: James Surowiecki: Why the Fed isn’t waging a war on savers.
item.description: Ben Bernanke may look like a mild-mannered academic, but, according to a chorus of critics, the chairman of the Federal Reserve is one of history’s great thieves. Over the past four years, the Fed has kept interest rates near zero and has pumped money into the economy . . .
item.dc:creator: James Surowiecki

item.title: Hisham Matar: In Libya, searching for a lost father.
item.description: 1. TRAPDOOR Early morning, March, 2012. My mother, my wife, Diana, and I were sitting in a row of seats that were bolted to the tiled floor of a lounge in Cairo International Airport. Flight 835 for Benghazi, a voice announced, was due to depart on time. Every now and . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Hisham Matar

item.title: Hilton Als: “Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me,” at the Tribeca Film Festival.
item.description: Elaine Stritch has a new documentary coming out, “Elaine Stritch: Shoot Me,” which will première at the Tribeca Film Festival on April 19. That’s the happy news. What isn’t happy news is that, after seventy-one years in New York, the eighty . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Hilton Als

item.title: Hendrik Hertzberg: Winning the semantic war over “entitlements.”
item.description: Names make news, an old newsroom motto has it. But names also make opinions. What something gets called can have more spin on it than a Mariano Rivera cutter, whether the person doing the calling intends it that way or not. Sometimes the difference between positive and negative is a . . .
item.dc:creator: Hendrik Hertzberg

item.title: Goings on About Town: The Theatre
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPENINGS AND PREVIEWS<!--/goatcategory--> Please call the phone number listed with the theatre for timetables and ticket information.
<!--goatTitle-->THE ASSEMBLED PARTIES<!--/goatTitle--> For Manhattan Theatre Club, Lynne Meadow directs this play by Richard Greenberg (“Take Me Out”), set in 1980 and 2000, about a Jewish . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Readings and Talks
item.description: goatTitle-->CHEZ ANDRÉ AT THE STANDARD HOTEL EAST VILLAGE<!--/goatTitle--> Two days before Leonard Cohen plays Radio City Music Hall (see Night Life), Sylvie Simmons reads from her latest book, “I’m Your Man: The Life of Leonard Cohen,” and performs Cohen songs on her ukulele . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: On the Horizon
item.description: ART SITTING DUKE April 16-July 14 In 1638, Velázquez, in order to curry favor with his patron, King Philip IV of Spain, invited the Duke of Modena to sit for him during the Duke’s visit to Madrid from Italy. The result, a masterpiece of Baroque . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Night Life
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->ROCK AND POP<!--/goatcategory--> Musicians and night-club proprietors live complicated lives; it’s advisable to check in advance to confirm engagements.
<!--goatTitle-->BEACON THEATRE<!--/goatTitle--> Broadway at 74th St. (212-465-6500)—April 7: This is the first of four area dates by Rodriguez in the singer . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Movies
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPENING<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->ANDRE GREGORY: BEFORE AND AFTER DINNER<!--/goatTitle--> A documentary portrait of the actor and director, by the filmmaker Cindy Kleine (who is also his wife). Opening April 3. (Film Forum.)
<!--goatTitle-->THE COMPANY YOU KEEP<!--/goatTitle--> Robert Redford directed this drama and also stars, as . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Dance
item.description: goatTitle-->CAMILLE A. BROWN<!--/goatTitle--> In “Mr. TOL E. RAncE,” Brown ventures into the taboo territory covered by Spike Lee in “Bamboozled”—the sensitive topic of black stereotypes in pop culture of the past and present. The piece tries to walk a fine line between . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Classical Music
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPERA<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->METROPOLITAN OPERA<!--/goatTitle--> April 3 and April 6 at 8: In 2010, Willy Decker brought a bit of (well-turned) Regietheater to the house with his stark and bracing production of “La Traviata,” which has entered Met lore as one of the company . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Art
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->MUSEUMS AND LIBRARIES<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->METROPOLITAN MUSEUM<!--/goatTitle--> Fifth Ave. at 82nd St. (212-535-7710)—“Impressionism, Fashion, and Modernity.” Through May 27. | “African Art, New York, and the Avant-Garde.” Through Sept. 2. | “The Path of Nature: French Paintings from the Wheelock Whitney . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Above and Beyond
item.description: goatTitle-->NORTH BROOKLYN BOAT CLUB<!--/goatTitle--> According to Jens Rasmussen, a founding member of this organization and its communications coördinator, “The club was born from desires to reclaim, protect, and celebrate one of North Brooklyn’s greatest natural resources—the waterways.” The club, which . . .

item.title: Gary J. Whitehead: “Soldier Course.”
item.description:
I watched them do the math, snap a powdered line. The brick saw whined a red dust. I’d wanted a path
to my back patio, same herringbone. I’d wanted a Weber, four chairs, an umbrella. The foreman’s name
was Hector. I gave him a . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Gary J. Whitehead

item.title: Emily Nussbaum: Modern cooking shows, from “Hell’s Kitchen” to “Barefoot Contessa.”
item.description: In 1968, Nora Ephron wrote a tart exposé of New York’s backbiting food establishment; at the end, she asked its members if haute cuisine would survive. “Of course it will last,” Poppy Cannon argued. “Just in the way sculpture will last.” Nika Hazelton . . .
item.dc:creator: Emily Nussbaum

item.title: Cover Story: Mark Ulriksen’s Baseball Art
item.description: A slide show of more New Yorker illustrations, sketchbooks, and covers about baseball by Mark Ulriksen.
item.dc:creator: Mina Kaneko and Francoise Mouly

item.title: Books: Sonali Deraniyagala’s “Wave” review.
item.description: In this quiet memoir of monstrous loss, Deraniyagala describes the death of her parents, her husband, and her two sons, Vikram and Malli, in the tsunami that struck the southern coast of Sri Lanka on Boxing Day, 2004. She returns to the care of relatives in Colombo, for a recovery . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: Marguerite Holloway’s “The Measure of Manhattan” review.
item.description: In 1808, the surveyor John Randel, Jr., was given the task of planning New York City’s grid of streets, and he soon faced threats from Manhattanites. Landowners above the settled lower end of the island expected that they would get to put streets where they wanted, and had . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: Gene Kerrigan’s “The Rage” review.
item.description: This tightly plotted crime novel is set in modern-day Dublin, a city struggling to right itself after the collapse of the “Celtic Tiger” bubble—a time when “all you needed to qualify for a big loan was a pulse.” When a corrupt banker is . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: A. B. Yehoshua’s “The Retrospective” review.
item.description: Much like the author himself, the novel’s protagonist is a cultural icon among Israel’s literati. He is Yair Moses, a film director whose prolific career is being surveyed in a retrospective held in a sleepy Spanish town. There Moses encounters a painting that overshadows the celebration . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Ben Greenman: “Lady” and “Adrian Younge Presents the Delfonics” reviews.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">Lady is possibly a bad name for a band, not because there’s anything wrong with it but because in this Google-happy era it’s almost impossible to search for the group without getting a million irrelevant results. It seems defiantly out of step . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Ben Greenman

item.title: Anthony Lane: “Trance” and “Blancanieves” reviews.
item.description: Take a mortar and pestle, the heftiest you can find. Tip in generous measures of “Memento” and “The Thomas Crown Affair,” plus any unconnected films that spring to mind. Pound with incessant fury. Voilà: you have “Trance,” the new movie from Danny Boyle . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Anthony Lane

item.title: Amelia Lester: The Pines in South Brooklyn review.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">If anyone knows how to get people to eat fancy food in unlikely places, it’s the crew behind the Pines. Seed money came from the owners of Littleneck, a clam shack a couple of storefronts down; on a good Friday night, when the room there . . .
item.dc:creator: Amelia Lester

item.title: Alex Ross: Shock tactics at the opera.
item.description: This year, opera on the East Coast has taken a turn toward the lurid, the sordid, the subversive, and the cryptic—in short, toward theatrical values that are more commonly found on European stages than on American ones, where patrons still expect Tosca in a tiara. The Met mounted . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Alex Ross

item.title: Adam Gopnik: Breakfast with Andre Gregory.
item.description: The director, avant-garde icon, and born raconteur Andre Gregory was having breakfast in the Village the other morning, and—as is his wont—was talking at length about the current state of his life, his art, and his soul. Andre, as he has been known, even to . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Adam Gopnik

item.title: The Crisis in a Nutshell: Quotes of the Week
item.description: “The notion that two months or three months after something as horrific as what happened in Newtown happens and we’ve moved on to other things? …That’s not who we are.”
item.dc:creator: Aswini Periyasamy

item.title: Weekend Reading: Unknown Unknowns, Free-Information Heroes, and Exiled Kings
item.description: One of the most mind-bending articles I read this week was Ethan Watters’s piece “We Aren’t the World,” from the Pacific Standard.
item.dc:creator: Andrea DenHoed

item.title: Backblogged: Our Five Favorite Sentences of the Week
item.description: The stream of stagey propaganda stills depicting Kim in an overcoat, staring grimly into the distance like a dinner-theatre performer in the role of MacArthur, leave unclear whether he is part of a performance he does not fully control.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Easter Covers
item.description: Easter is here, and this holiday weekend we’ve rounded up a selection of imaginative Easter covers from the past two decades. Spanning from 1993 to 2010, these often whimsical images reflect the buoyant spirit of the season.
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Come Play with “The Shining”
item.description: “The Shining,” released in May, 1980, has always been seen as Stanley Kubrick’s pulpiest and most commercial venture. It’s not just that it’s a horror film. (All of Kubrick’s works, really, are horror films.)...
item.dc:creator: Bill Wyman

item.title: Toyo Ito’s Pritzker Win
item.description: The new Pritzker Prize winner Toyo Ito (who will receive his medal in a May ceremony at Boston’s John F. Kennedy Presidential Library) is a seventy-one-year-old Japanese architect with a distinguished forty-year record of substantial and influential buildings, some of them much admired. And yet, as much as Ito’s Pritzker acknowledges his indisputable skill and endurance, the prize also illuminates some of the deep weirdness of architecture as a profession.
item.dc:creator: Thomas de Monchaux

item.title: A Frenzy of Threat
item.description: A menacing tone was set as soon as the first lighting cue came up, in silence: eight narrow strips of light crossing the floor from end to end, which created a sharp, forbidding environment, a trap that awaited unsuspecting victims.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Boynton

item.title: “V.” at L: Pynchon’s First Novel Turns Fifty
item.description: To read “V.” today is to experience Pynchon anew. Blast through the multilayered densities of “Gravity’s Rainbow,” “Mason & Dixon,” and “Against the Day,” and you have a young Cornell graduate, an engineer from Long Island, writing with an earnestness you might not have expected, about a world he could never recover.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Nazaryan

item.title: Trailer Trash
item.description: It seemed as though we had survived a dark time, and made it safely to the other side, when roughly two minutes and twenty seconds of the new “Star Trek” trailer had elapsed without...
item.dc:creator: Ian Crouch

item.title: Book News: Amazon Recommends, Cat-Like Tread
item.description: Amazon has bought the book-recommendation site Goodreads. An interview with Renata Adler about the writing life, rereading your old work, and why so much writing today is “like a race to join the herd...
item.dc:creator: Andrea DenHoed

item.title: Political Scene: Moving Gay Marriage Forward
item.description: This week, the Supreme Court heard oral arguments in two cases dealing with gay marriage: the challenges to California’s Proposition 8 and the federal Defense of Marriage Act. On the Political Scene podcast, Jeffery Toobin and Margaret Talbot talk with Dorothy Wickenden about how the Court might rule in each case and what the decisions could mean for marriage equality.
item.dc:creator: Matthew McKnight

item.title: Hey Look!
item.description: The New Yorker cartoonists and comics fans Benjamin Schwartz and Liam Francis Walsh took a trip to the Society of Illustrators to see The Art of Harvey Kurtzman. (Through May 11th, Society of Illustrators, 128 East Sixty-third Street.)
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Schwartz and Liam Francis Walsh
